quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to print "Hi".
[!raw!]
>>> {0}("Hi")
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Your First Program[/h1]

Let's start off by creating a short program that displays "Hello world!".
In Python, we use the [b]print [/b]statement to output text: [code format="py" codeId="283"]>>> print('Hello world!')
Hello world![/code]
Congratulations! You have written your first program.
[note]Run, save, and share your Python code on our [b]Code Playground[/b] without installing any additional software. 
When using a computer, you will need to download and install Python from www.python.org.
Note the >>> in  the code above. They are the prompt symbol of the Python console. Python is an interpreted language, which means that each line is executed as it is entered. Python also includes [b]IDLE[/b], the integrated development environment, which includes tools for writing and debugging entire programs.[/note]

[h1]Printing Text[/h1]

The [b]print[/b] statement can also be used to output multiple lines of text.
[b]For Example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="284"]>>> print('Hello world!')
Hello world!
>>> print('Hello world!')
Hello world!
>>> print('Spam and eggs...')
Spam and eggs...[/code]
[note]Python code often contains references to the comedy group [b]Monty Python[/b]. This is why the words, "spam" and "eggs" are often used as placeholder variables in Python where "foo" and "bar" would be used in other programming languages.[/note]
